column1: José Juventino Policarpo Rosas Cadenas (25 January 1868 – 9 July 1894) was a Mexican composer and violinist.
Rosas was born in Santa Cruz
column3: later renamed Santa Cruz de Galeana
column5: and still later into Santa Cruz de Juventino Rosas. Rosas began his musical career as a street musician
column6: playing with dance music bands in Mexico City. In 1884-85 and 1888 he enrolled into the conservatory
column7: both times leaving it without taking any examination.

column1: Most of Rosas's compositions—among them "Sobre las Olas" ("Over the Waves")—were issued by Wagner y Levien and Nagel Sucesores in Mexico City.

column2: Rosas is reported to be a member of a military band
column3: and in 1891 he worked in Michoacán. In 1892–93 Rosas lived near Monterrey before joining an orchestra in 1893 for a tour through the USA. During this tour
column4: the group performed at the World Columbian Exposition World's Fair in Chicago

column2: Rosas went for a several-month tour to Cuba with an Italian-Mexican ensemble
column3: where he came down with major health problems
column4: having to stay behind in Surgidero de Batabanó. As a result of spinal myelitis
column5: he died there at the age of 26.  Fifteen years later
column7: his remains were brought back to Mexico.

column1: Rosas is one of the best known Mexican composers of salon music
column2: as well as the one with the highest number of editions abroad and of sound recordings
column3: the first of them released in 1898.

column1: Rosas's best known work is "Sobre las Olas" or "Over the Waves". It was first published in Mexico in 1888. It remains popular as a classic waltz
column2: and has also found its way into New Orleans Jazz
column4: Country and Western music and Tejano music. In the United States "Sobre las Olas" has a cultural association with funfairs
column7: as it was one of the tunes available for Wurlitzer's popular line of fairground organs. The music was used for the tune "The Loveliest Night of the Year"
column8: which was sung by Ann Blyth in MGM's film The Great Caruso.  It remains still popular with country and old-time fiddlers in the United States.

column1: The 1950 film Over the Waves was based on his life.
